Study: Detection and isolation of asymptomatic individuals can make the difference in COVID-19 epidemic management medrxiv
Factors: reduction in traveling between communities within the Mendoza province
Excerpt: N/A; outbreak reached the West with a 17-day lag (Ro=4) and a 42-day delay (Ro=2) when traveling between communities was reduced to a tenth
Measure of Evidence: Countries: Argentina cities: Mendoza; Timeline: none

Study: Household Secondary Attack Rate of COVID-19 and Associated Determinants
Factors: case isolation/quarantine's effect on close contacts
Excerpt: a COVID-19 case infected 0.48 (95% CI: 0.39-0.58) close contacts; had isolation not been implemented, this number increases to 0.62 (95% CI: 0.51-0.75)
Measure of Evidence: Countries: China cities: Guangzhou; Timeline: Feb 17th 2020

Study: A hybrid multi-scale model of COVID-19 transmission dynamics to assess the potential of non-pharmaceutical interventions
Factors: case isolation/isolation of exposed individuals (i.e. quarantine) to prevent secondary transmission in health care and community settings
Excerpt: The model predicts that, in the absence of any control intervention, the disease will infect 98.4 % of the system population by the of the simulation time. The model predicts that the case fatality rate (CFR) is 6.5%.; If 80% of the population stayed home, there would be an infection rate of 30%

Study: COVID-19 infection and recovery in various countries: Modeling the dynamics and evaluating the non-pharmaceutical mitigation scenarios
Factors: attempted quarantine (forced quarantine for infected individuals before the outbreak)
Excerpt: No quarantine: total number of infected people 9,336; Attempted quarantine: total number of infected people 9,322

Study: Symptom-Based Isolation Policies: Evidence from a Mathematical Model of Outbreaks of Influenze and COVID-19
Factors: symptom based isolation
Excerpt: 50% of the cases detect fever: no isolation: attack rate is 79% (IQR: 56-90%); one day post-fever isolation reduces attack rate to 71% (IQR: 43-86%)

Study: Interventions to mitigate early spread of SARS-CoV-2 in Singapore: a modelling study
Factors: isolation measures for infected individuals and quarantining of family members
Excerpt: R0 = 1.5 270,000 people infected (7.4% population); The combined intervention decreased the median cumulative infection count on day 80 to 1800 (200–23 000; table; appendix p 9), representing a 99·3% (IQR 92·6–99·9) reduction from the baseline scenario

Study: Effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of public health measures to control COVID-19: a modelling study
Factors: isolation of infected cases and quarantine of humans exposed to the cases
Excerpt: N/A; The effective reproduction number (Re) was 1.84 (95%CI: 1.81, 1.87) and 3.80 (95%CI: 3.53, 4.06) respectively when the transmission constant was one in scenario I and II (Additional file 1: Table S4). Varying the transmission constant from the 0.25 to two, the isolation-and-quarantine was the most cost-effective single intervention, and program A was the most cost-effective joint intervention.

Study: The Effectiveness of Social Distancing in Mitigating COVID-19 Spread: a modelling analysis medrxiv
Factors: increased case isolation
Excerpt: 66% infection rate (179,788 infected individuals) - no activation delay; With no significant activation delay, the most effective single measure is the 70% reduction in community-wide contact. This reduces the infection attack rate to approximately a third, from 180,000 to 64,000 (Table 3) and from 66% of the population down to 24%
Measure of Evidence: Countries: Australia; cities: Newcastle; Timeline: 10 weeks
